dialogue.statement: Hello! What would you like to talk about today? Feel free to share what's on your mind or any challenges you're facing. I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey, so I've been thinking a lot about going back to college, but I'm worried because I felt completely unprepared last time. Just trying to figure out what I can do differently this time to succeed.
It sounds like returning to college is important to you, but there are some worries about feeling unprepared. What do you think contributed to those feelings last time?
client: I think a lot of it was just the shock of realizing how much I was missing in terms of academic skills. It made me feel like I was starting from scratch and it was super overwhelming.

It must have felt daunting to face the realization of needing to catch up on academic skills. What aspects of going back to college are you looking forward to, and are there specific skills you'd like to develop this time around?

I'm actually excited about the idea of learning and growing, especially in subjects I'm interested in. I'd really like to improve my time management and study skills so I can keep up and feel more confident in my classes.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their experiences and feelings about being underprepared for college, including specific academic and personal challenges. They have also expressed excitement about learning and areas for skill development. Empathy has been established, but mutually agreed goals are not yet clear. Continuation in Exploring will help to further clarify goals and build rapport.

dialogue.statement: I can sense your enthusiasm for learning and growing, especially in areas that interest you. Focusing on time management and study skills sounds like a great way to build confidence. What experiences have you had with managing your time or studying that you think might help you as you go back to college?

client(exploring): Honestly, in the past, I've kind of just winged it, which clearly didn't work out too well. But I've since tried using planners and setting small goals for myself in other areas, which has helped a bit.

statement.reasoning: The essence of the client’s story, including feelings of being unprepared due to high school experience and excitement for learning, has been effectively elicited. Relevant context and emotional responses have been explored, and rapport seems well established. The client's goals and areas of interest are also identified. It's appropriate to move to Guiding to strengthen motivation for change.

dialogue.statement: It sounds like you've made some progress with using planners and setting small goals, which could be really beneficial as you return to college. How do you envision these strategies fitting into your college experience, and what positive changes do you think they might bring?

I'm hoping that sticking to a planner and setting small goals will help me stay on top of assignments and manage my time better. I think it'll make a big difference in keeping me organized and reducing that overwhelming feeling I had before.

Using a planner and setting small goals indeed seem like promising strategies for staying organized and reducing overwhelm. How might these changes align with your broader goals for college and beyond, and what steps could reinforce your confidence in these new approaches?

I think aligning these changes with my broader goals could really boost my confidence, like seeing progress on a regular basis would be encouraging. Reinforcing them might involve keeping track of my achievements and reminding myself why I'm doing this whenever I feel stuck or unsure.

Tracking your achievements and reminding yourself of your reasons for pursuing college sounds like a powerful way to stay motivated and confident. How does the idea of regularly reflecting on your progress resonate with you, and in what ways could this reflection support your journey towards your broader life goals?

client(guiding): Regularly reflecting on my progress sounds like a great way to stay motivated and keep my goals in sight. I think it could help me see the steps I'm taking and not just focus on what's left to do, which makes the whole journey feel more manageable and real.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively addressed the client's ambivalence by exploring their concerns and strategies for change. Change Talk is present, with specific goals like using a planner and setting small goals. The client seems confident about these strategies aligning with broader goals, indicating readiness to develop an action plan.

dialogue.statement: Reflecting on your progress and seeing the steps you're taking towards your goals truly seems empowering and can make the journey feel tangible and achievable. As you consider the next steps, what specific action plan might you create to incorporate these reflections, and how would you like to address any potential challenges that might arise along the way?

client(choosing): I guess creating a routine where I check in with myself weekly could be a good start, like maybe setting aside some time on Sundays to review the past week and plan for the next. For potential challenges, I'd want to have a support system in place, maybe by reaching out to classmates or using campus resources if I hit a rough patch.

Having a weekly check-in routine sounds like a solid plan to help you stay on track and prepare for the upcoming week. Considering a support system with classmates and campus resources is a wise approach to tackle challenges. Based on what you mentioned, possible steps could include scheduling your Sunday reflections and identifying specific campus resources or classmates you feel comfortable reaching out to. How does that sound, and what steps do you think you could take to implement this plan?

client(choosing): That sounds really doable. I could start by actually putting it in my calendar as a recurring event to make it feel official. As for campus resources, I think I'll try to find out more about study groups or tutoring services. Reaching out to classmates might be a bit out of my comfort zone, but it's something I should definitely consider.

Setting a recurring event in your calendar for your Sunday reflections is a fantastic way to commit to your routine, making it a tangible part of your week. Exploring study groups or tutoring services on campus could provide additional support and resources. Reaching out to classmates, though challenging, might also offer valuable connections and insights. What small steps could you take to start exploring these resources, and how would you like to approach reaching out to classmates, even if it's just a small step at first?

client(choosing): I think a good start would be to attend any campus orientations or info sessions to learn about study groups and tutoring services. As for reaching out to classmates, maybe I could start by introducing myself to a few people in my classes or forming a small study group with whoever seems interested. Even just saying hi or asking a question could be a small step towards building those connections.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan, including a weekly reflection routine and identifying campus resources. They have also addressed potential barriers by considering a support system. The client expresses a commitment to their plan and confidence in their ability to implement it, suggesting readiness to advance.

dialogue.statement: Attending campus orientations and info sessions is an excellent step to familiarize yourself with available resources. Taking that initial step to introduce yourself to classmates and exploring the idea of forming a study group shows a great willingness to build connections, even if it's just starting with a simple 'hi' or a question. These small steps can lead to meaningful support systems over time. As you move forward, remember that each step, no matter how small, contributes to your progress and helps you stay grounded and motivated. You've got a thoughtful plan in place, and I believe in your ability to make these changes. Keep tracking your progress and reaching out when needed. You've got this!
Thanks for the encouragement! I'll definitely try to put myself out there a bit more and see what happens. It feels good to know I have a plan.

statement.reasoning: The session effectively concluded with a summary of strategies, a next-step plan, and encouragement for the client’s college journey. The client's concerns were addressed, and they expressed feeling encouraged with a plan to move forward.

concern:
title: what can i do if high school severely under-prepared me for college?
to summarize, my HS was a (very brand new) trade school that had a lot of issues with classes and credits when i was enrolled there. i graduated with pretty good grades and got into a college i wanted, but upon trying to register for classes, i realized i hadn’t even met the requirements to take prerequisite courses of stuff like english and math. let alone the complete lack of any extracurriculars, since they weren’t offered in HS. i got enrolled in some of the most base level courses in college and it really demotivated me and made me feel like i wasn’t getting anywhere. that plus mental health and a few other factors made me drop out half a semester into my first year. 

it’s been a long while since then and i’m thinking about going back, but i still only have what i had from HS and that’s it, not even personal portfolios or anything else. is there anything i should do before i try to reenroll? or is there any strategies i could try to do what i need while also not falling behind? thank you :)
